Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research at the Intersection of Biology and Mathematics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU Site award to the Florida Institute of Technology, located in Melbourne, FL will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2015-2017. The REU program is open to all undergraduate students who are citizens, nationals or permanent residents of the United States. Students trained in the program will gain skills in lab research, develop their critical thinking and problem-solving skills, understand the process of science, and be able to communicate their research results to their peers and the general public. Students will have an opportunity to present their results at a national conference. The REU program provides an experience to students that is typically not available to them at their home institutions. Students from schools with limited opportunities for research and from underrepresented groups are encouraged to apply.

This REU Site program will recruit students interested in integrating biology and mathematics research. There is a need to greatly improve the quantitative and computational skills of students in biology as well as capture the interest of mathematicians and computer scientists in addressing emerging problems in biology. There will be a strong emphasis on problem solving and the direct application of modern mathematical and computational methods to current problems in the biological sciences ranging from cell and molecular biology to ecology. Students will work in teams on a specific research problem with significant support from faculty.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students are required to be tracked after the program and must respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information is available by visiting http://research.fit.edu/reu/biomath/biomath.php, or by contacting the PI (Dr. David Carroll at dcarroll@fit.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Munevver Subasi at msubasi@fit.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The BioMath REU at the Florida Institute of Technology is an interdisciplinary program that brought together faculty from the Departments of Mathematical Sciences and Biological Sciences. The faculty worked together to guide teams of two undergraduate research interns - one majoring in Mathematics and the other in Biology. The research interns were involved in all aspects of the research project - from designing and interpreting experiments to guiding the direction of inquiry. In addition to working in the laboratory, the interns were also involved in weekly group meetings covering current topics in biomathematics, getting into graduate school, succeeding in graduate school, and career development. All students also received training and weekly practice in learning the software program “R”. At the end of each summer research period, the student teams presented their work in talks and research posters during a University-wide research day. Over the four-year period of this award, we trained 32 students; 29 women and three men, including two African-Americans, three Hispanic-Americans, one Chinese-American, one Indian-American and three from universities with limited research opportunities. Furthermore, products such as a scientific software program to easily track and measure distance in photomicrographs, presentations at national meetings, and scientific publications have been developed as a result of this project. Intellectual Merit: The research projects in this proposal addressed significant basic research problems at the intersection of Biology and Mathematics, including: (1) ﻿ A genetic basis for the invasiveness of the Bluegill Sunfish (Lepomis macrochirus) and Redear and comparison of their genetic variations with other species; (2) Human Impacts on Diatoms Assemblages in an Amazonian Lake over the last 2300 years; ﻿(3) Isolation of a Quorum Sensing Regulator  in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii; ﻿(4) Identification of Signaling Molecules in Starfish Eggs through Bioinformatics; (5) Identification of genetic signatures associated with melanoma subtypes and drug resistivity; and (6) Risk stratification and survival analysis of African-American Study of Chronic Kidney Disease with Hypertension. Although the projects were very different in scope, the cohesive theme for the program was to address these biological problems using a variety of mathematical methods, including image processing, statistical analysis, mathematical modeling, and machine learning. Broader Impacts: The primary objectives of this program were to: 1) Provide an enriched research and learning experience in BioMathematics for undergraduate scientists at the Florida Institute of Technology: This objective was accomplished. Of the 32 research interns supported under this program, 17 have since graduated from college and they all remain involved in some aspect of biomathematics; either in graduate school in mathematics or biology, in medical school, or working in a related field. The remaining 15 students are all still completing undergraduate degrees in either mathematics or biology-related majors. 2) To prepare students for careers in the burgeoning fields of modeling, biostatistics, and bioinformatics. The goal was accomplished through project activities, where each of the projects required students to use mathematical, statistical and bioinformatics tools. As indicated by the career paths taken by the BioMath REU interns, we feel that this goal was also accomplished. Overall, we are pleased with the success of this program. It provided great benefit to the participating students - motivating them to continue in a path that involved biomathematics and stimulating many of them to pursue graduate degrees in this area.
